questions.question: He is so pigheaded you can’t reason with him.
questions.description: Here so modifies the adjective pigheaded. Only an adverb can modify an adjective.

questions.question: Sailing alone around the world was quite a pilgrimage.
questions.description: Quite is an adverb indicating degree. It shows to what extent.

questions.question: The admiral was always nonchalant in the face of danger.
questions.description: Always is an adverb of time. It answers the question when.

questions.question: A person’s outward appearance was formerly thought to reveal his character.
questions.description: Formerly is an adverb of time. Most words ending in ly are adverbs.

questions.question: Wearing nothing but blue clothing is only one of her peculiarities.
I have told you this twice.
questions.description: Twice is an adverb of frequency. It answers the question how often.

questions.question: That day he arrived late.
questions.description: Here late modifies the verb arrived. Hence it is an adverb.

questions.question: I have already spoken to him about this.
My dog understands everything. He is almost human.
questions.description: Here the adverb almost modifies the adjective human.

questions.question: I am fully prepared for the examination.
questions.description: Here the adverb fully modifies the adjective prepared.
